headline: New showdown over immigration amid a Trump tweetstorm
subHeadline: President Trump says there will be no deal on DACA and steps up calls for tougher border security. Reaction on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is extremely dangerous to our democracy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is extremely dangerous to our democracy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is extremely dangerous to our democracy.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: BRIAN STELTER, CNN

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. Come on, Brian. Given CNN's obsession over Stormy, maybe you want to tape this script on the company fridge. And how could it be worse than CNN's mission statement?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Who was high on mushrooms when they wrote that? But Stelter wasn't the only media mouth freaking out. So why was the howling media triggered by this? Well, maybe they feel threatened. People are saying what they're really about, finally. Or maybe, just maybe, this is what angry people do on Easter Sunday and that's even more depressing. So Kimberly, as a mission statement, what exactly was so outrageous about that and the fact that they read it? It was a great audiovisual of putting it together.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Right. It was how they packaged it to put it together to make it sound like groupthink.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Like cultish.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Et cetera. Very much like a cult or something like everybody drank the Kool-Aid. But no, but if you look at it and, like, actually examine the separate and disparate parts, you see it's, in fact, just journalists trying to do their job. But I'm also then reminded in the juxtaposition of how good FOX News is where you look at all the different local clips across. And like, we really do have the best people, I just have to say. Well done.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dana, I think Jimmy Kimmel tweeted that this is a threat to democracy or something like that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I think that also, you have to remember who it's coming from. Right? So this is Sinclair. This is a group that is working on their merger right now. And what's interesting is I think the way that -- every news organization markets themselves as being the source for truth, the source for the best information --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO

Contrast that with the new media campaign that FOX News is doing, which was super sophisticated, very different. And the thing that was really different about it from my perspective is that there was no script. So we went in there not knowing what we were going to be asked or what we were actually going to say. Maybe thought about it a little bit. But all of that is very spontaneous, and authenticity is what I think viewers are looking for. And if you're making fun of that thing, you could probably see that it was not authentic.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: We just showed up with a few different colored outfits.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: And then the rest was, like, let it fly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And it's intellectually good. And it's different; it's very modern. And --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. We changed three times.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Nobody was telling us, as every day here, no one tells us what to say --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: -- what to do, what to think. And that's why it's genuinely authentic, and it shows in the Pew research in the polls. The people trust us.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I still think this is unfair. I think this is a mission statement that they read, and so that's what you do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, they read it, because they can't afford to spend all the money that FOX spends on a really nice promotional campaign. And that's fine. They don't have the budget, so they did what they did. It's the same thing, as you said, as the CNN promo. You hit the nail on the head. CNN is threatened by it, because they know that this Sinclair piece was targeting a place like CNN. You know, this brings me back to the Fake News Awards. Let's remind everybody some of these awards. CNN, Don Jr. and WikiLeaks, false. The Mooch story about Russia, falls. The fake Japanese feeding the fish video, false. Brian Ross, ABC tank market. What do all these things have in common? They're all fake news from the liberal mainstream media, and they were all done in order to hurt President Trump. So when you combine that with the fact that 90 percent of D.C. journalists are Democrats, and 90 percent of the nightly evening news from the networks are against Donald Trump, people understand in this country that the mainstream media is biased, and they calculate that when they watch the news.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Last word, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I think it's telling that Donald Trump immediately defended Sinclair. And I think that indicates to me how political this was. So you can say it was a mission statement from a corporate owner, but it's a corporate owner that really controls a lot of local media. And I think the understanding people have when they, you know, if they tune in to us, they say, "Well, that's national media, and I understand the roles that are being played, left, right, all that." But when they turn on their local news to learn about tax assessments in the school board, I think they're surprised that this kind of lockstep, lack of independence would exist. And I think that was the power here. That this is not independent anymore. Your local news is now under control of somebody who is pro-Trump. And Trump is defending them. Because the message, although you see it as not having any bias, it fits the Trump message perfectly, which is you are being assaulted by fake news that's unfriendly to me and not to be believed. And so now coming in your local news, people see this as insidious.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think it actually fits the FOX News message, fair and balanced. That's all they were saying. And No. 2, I would urge people to actually read the actual transcript. Because when you look at the video, all you see in here are the sounds. No one is actually listening. So I think that if you read it, it's not political at all. And it's not Trump. Because remember, Trump came after fair and balanced.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, this is -- this is a context. You have to ask people to read it in the context. They read it without that, they'll say it's no big deal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Read the whole thing. All right. Coming up, Kellyanne Conway responds to allegations she's the No. 1 leaker in the White House.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: A new book on the Trump White House making some headlines ahead of its release. This one written by Ron Kessler, who claims he knows where all those leaks are coming from: Kellyanne Conway.

utterances.speaker: RON KESSLER, AUTHOR
utterances.sentences: I know that White House aides have seen texts that she has sent to other journalists dissing her colleagues, leaking material. So if you wonder, you know, why there are so many leaks out of the White House, one reason is Kellyanne is the No. 1 leaker.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: FOX asked Ms. Conway for her response this morning.

utterances.speaker: KELLYANNE CONWAY, COUNSELOR TO DONALD TRUMP
utterances.sentences: He knows, and he has said publicly and privately who the leakers on the liars are and have been. Very happy that there's a lot less leaking in the White House. Leakers get great press. And one day, Abby, I will have my say.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow. So Dana, you're a White House person. What do you think? What's the truth here?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: She's right. Like, the book she writes is the one everyone is going to want to read. Because she'll finally be able to be free and talk about it. I think she is indicating that there was somebody at the White House who is no longer there working at the White House who she thinks was the big leaker. My experience is that people who are the leakers are the one who complain about it first and like saying, like, "Oh, my gosh. Did you see this leak?" And like, oh, yes, you're the leaker. She doesn't seem like the one who does that to me. But I've never been the -- I don't know. I've never been the recipient of any White House leaks, so I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, you would have been the leaker.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No. Let me tell you, communications people don't leak ever.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, is that true?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You have to clean up the mess of everybody else.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's a really good cover.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't think that's -- I don't think that's true, let me just say.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You're telling me White House press secretaries don't leak?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, because you're on the record.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, no, no. They leak. I can personally attest to this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Not me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, not you. I would say not you. Jesse, what's interesting in this is I know Ron Kessler. Terrific reporter but a big Trump supporter, and in fact, someone who's gone down to Mar-a- Lago with Trump, likes Trump a lot. All of a sudden, here he is attacking Kellyanne. What do you make of this?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm confused by it. Kessler is a good author. A lot of the times the books are salacious and gossipy. Although he is a good author, and he does sell a lot of books. I don't know what to think of it. I've always seen Kellyanne as a straight shooter, and she is very supported by the president. One if not the best and most articulate defender of the president of the United States and is one of, if not the best and most articulate defender of the president. So I don't think she's the leaker. I don't know that for a fact, but I do know if Dana was to leak, she would not leak to you, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Is that right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Never. Never.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Excellent.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'd be leaking to Jesse Watters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right. That's right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Kellyanne is going to be on "Watters' World"?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: It's like --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The truth teller. I call on the truth teller.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes, the truth teller. I mean, come on, everybody knows who the leakers are, were, in the White House. Kellyanne not one of them. And so I think when she has her day --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: -- you know, to be able to tell the truth about what went on there, she's going to have a very revealing and not surprising story to tell in terms of what transpired there. So I've never known her to leak, to do anything like that. And I know other people who have. That's for sure.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So Greg, the one last thing I'd say is that, according to Kessler, Ivanka and Jared are problems. That's what Kessler writes. And he said that they were involved with firing Comey and hiring Scaramucci.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I actually believe Kessler on this, because I don't think that -- what's her name again?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Kellyanne.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Kellyanne, I don't think she's the leaker. I think she's a human being. And this White House is not a perfect White House. It's a human being White House. That means people talk and they complain and they vent. So I don't think anybody is actually leaking. They're just walking around venting, and people hear it. By the way, I have an idea for a sponsored segment on this show. Call it "Leak of the Day." It could be sponsored by Poise. It would be great.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Got to go.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Got to go.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right. "One More Thing" -- you want to get out of here. "One More Thing" up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's time now for "One More Thing." Juan hits -- kicks us off. Hits us off?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It's April, time for high school college seniors to open those make-or-break college acceptance letters. This year's big winner across the nation is a 17-year-old from Houston, Michael Brown. He got into Stanford, but that's just 1 of 20 schools that accepted the young man. And he got into all of those schools and also got full scholarships to all of them. His mom, who's a drug counselor, says her dreams have come true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's awesome. Good for him. Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, Stanford was my safety school. Nice try.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Nice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The guy in Sarasota, we're going to call him a Florida man, went out to his backyard to go for a swim around midnight, and guess what he found?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, dear.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: An 11-foot alligator swimming in his pool in Florida. He called some people, they said get out of the pool, and he was safe. But I mean, look at that thing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's a big thing.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: My gosh, look at how much fun it was having. It was like how I feel when I'm in the hot tub.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Greg, you're next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. First, if you go to Berkeley, you've got to start making shirts that say "Stanford was My Safety School." You have to do that. All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I want a cut.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I hate these people!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. If you're in a meeting -- let's say it's an H.R. meeting, or its traffic school, or it's records preservation training -- and at the end of the meeting, someone says, "Does anybody have any questions?" Don't ask a question. Nobody likes the person that asked a question, especially when it's nice outside or it's the end of the day. Go -- if you have a question, go on Google.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Find out that question there, answer that question.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's a good answer. Everyone should listen to that. A good point. Everyone should listen to his advice. All right. People who know Jasper know he likes to look for fish. If you follow me on Instagram, he's always every day fishing, everywhere he can. This weekend, not only was it Easter yesterday, but Jasper caught a fish. Check him out. A big one. Check him out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Nice.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The other thing is, it was April Fool's, and I got so many people on that. He didn't catch the fish. Don't forget, "Let Me Tell You About Jasper," it comes out in paperback tomorrow. Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Very, very cute. OK, so a little bit of damp weather was no match for this year's 140th annual White House Easter egg roll. Nearly 30,000 adults and children joined the first lady on the White House lawn. It was packed with fun. Melania Trump, Betsy DeVos and Kellyanne Conway were among those featured as readers this year. And this goes back to 1878.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: A great event. "Special Report" is up next. Hey, Bret.

utterances.speaker: BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Does Greg have any questions? Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2018 CQ-Roll Call, Inc. All materials herein are protected by United States copyright law and may not be reproduced, distributed, transmitted, displayed, published or broadcast without the prior written permission of CQ-Roll Call. You may not alter or remove any trademark, copyright or other notice from copies of the content.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Kimberly Guilfoyle, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City and this is "The Five." No more deals on "dreamers," President Trump spending part of his Easter Sunday fuming over Democratic roadblock to his immigration agenda. He's now urging Republicans to use the nuclear options to pass new border legislation. He said DACA is dead because the Democrats didn't care or act.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Mexico has got to help us at the border. And a lot of people are coming in because they want to take advantage of DACA. And we're going to have to really see. They had a great chance. The Democrats blew it. They had a great, great chance. But we'll have to take a look.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: His press secretary, Sarah Sanders, followed up on Fox News earlier today.

utterances.speaker: SARAH SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.utterance: The president made multiple offers on DACA. He wanted to see something get done. And Democrats refused to actually put something on the table or work with the president to get anything done. They wanted these DACA recipients as political pawns. Look, the president wanted to make a deal. He made two incredibly generous offers that went far and above even what the previous administration had done on DACA, and Democrats still refused to make a deal. And I think it's because we're getting close to an election. They don't want to see the president continue to win like he has for the last year and a half.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jesse, I'll go to you first. There is a debate on who killed DACA, right? So the Democrats are saying, well, he killed DACA, they killed DACA. I think the truth is it wasn't going to go anywhere before this midterm election. Anyway, everyone is going to try to utilize this for their advantage in the midterms.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Exactly. You know, the president offered a very generous proposal, and crying Chuck denied it several times. That's fine. The reason we're in this situation is because President Obama put forth DACA, and he knew it was unconstitutional because for the two years before and he'd said I wasn't allowed to do it as president. Then he changed and he did it. It was challenge in the courts. It was about to get rejected, so the president comes along and says let's have congress deal with immigration law because that's the right place.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: . to deal with immigration law. So, he comes out and he puts forth an arrangement which I thought was overly generous. It was 1.8 million amnesty in exchange for wall funding. That was rejected. So the president try to make it a broader solution and say, OK, let's put things that the American people want on the table, merit-based immigration system and doing away with the visa lottery and with chain migration.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yep.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Seventy five percent of the country believes that. That was rejected as well. So, we're now in a situation where the Democrats are going to campaign in the midterms as the Republicans hate Hispanics. And the Republicans will campaign in the midterms as the Democrats want illegal immigration and open borders. And we're just going to see which narrative wins.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Here's that DNC deputy chair, Keith Ellison, to that point on what he thinks of it.

utterances.speaker: KEITH ELLISON, DNC DEPUTY CHAIR
utterances.utterance: Back when Trump ended the DACA program back in September, I knew he wasn't going to do anything about it. He never had a plan for trying to fix DACA and he turned down several bipartisan deals. It was always a game. It was always a trick. He was never arguing in good faith.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Juan, the president did put a pretty generous plan on the table for going beyond the DACA kids to say that there would be up to 8 million that he would be willing to do, basically, an amnesty for. And it couldn't get done. Is there -- is it fair to say that for the Democrats this is an election issue is better for them than solving the problem?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: No. I think, in fact, the Democrats would like to crow, Dana, that they have solved the problem and saved the dreamers. And what you see is, in fact, the proposal that the president put forward didn't even have the support of enough Republican votes in the senate to get past. So Republicans didn't back what the president.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, he didn't.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He need 60.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, he need 60.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah, he had 36.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He need 60.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He had 36 Republicans, so he didn't even had the 52 Republicans behind him. I think what struck me was how little relationship there is between what the president was tweeting and reality. He says these people -- there's a caravan, as you know, of people from Honduras, Guatemala, trying to make their way up to the U.S. border to request asylum because they're fleeing from the crime and the chaos down there. And the president says these people are trying to take advantage of the dreamers. Well, they can't apply for a dreamers status. There's no relationship. But he makes it as if it's one. And then he goes on to argue as if somehow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It is related, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, tell me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, because if you cross the border illegally as a migrant seeking asylum, you will get special treatment and they'll consider you for amnesty.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, they'll consider you for asylum.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Amnesty or asylum, you still get to stay in this country and have protected status.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But there's nothing -- I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yeah, under consideration.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right. So there's nothing -- there's a huge difference. In order to qualify for DACA, Jesse, you have to have been in the country, you have to come in to the country at a very young age.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There's no argument that not having a border wall and having the DACA situation still in play does attract illegal immigration from the southern border.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Kimberly, if you're being technical.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . then, yes, these people that are applying for asylum are not -- or children being brought across the border by their parents. But it is true that there is this caravan. It comes around every year. This is the fifth year this group has tried to do this. And they tried to deter them. So, like, you're not going to get asylum here. Like, you might be able to try to apply for it. And Nikki Haley was actually in Honduras just this past spring and saying, if we want to help you solve this problem at its source, but you're going to have to partner with us.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, isn't that reasonable, though? I mean, she's going right to the source of the problem and saying, look, we like to partner with you. We like to find a positive solution for this. But nevertheless, you can't just, you know, flagrantly violate the law and expect for the law to show you consideration at expense to others who are comporting themselves in an appropriate matter and following the legal guidelines. Nobody is trying to, like, step on anybody's dreams or hopes or ability to get into this country. What people are against is illegal entry. And let me tell you something, the president was giving the Democrats, and they missed a great opportunity here to take advantage of this positioning, and of what he wanted was to get the 25 billion for his enhanced border wall. And instead, they went ahead and passed on it for political reasons, which is a disservice to everyone. Because, really, it was 80 percent of what they want, OK. And he's just was saying, listen, we've got to, like, slow it down about this in terms of chain migration and this lottery system, and put some more specific standards and practices. Little bit more structure to make sure that the right people are getting in and it's properly background vetted, etcetera. That's not an unreasonable request. What's unreasonable is the obstructionists on both sides, to be quite frank, because people acted like political party pigs and they wanted everything they wanted on their plate without an ability or reason to compromise. And now, this is what we have. So, the president didn't kill DACA. I mean, I think the Democrats killed it. And people who were too entrenched in their own political beliefs and won't willing to compromise.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second. Who killed DACA?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a minute. Who ended DACA? President Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No, he did not.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Sort of a tit for tat. You killed it. No, I killed it, whatever. Basically, it's not getting done before the election.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes. It's like murder on the Orient Express. They've all killed DACA.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. I've ruined the ending for you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I love Agatha Christie.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I love all of her paperbacks. Anyway, I believe this group that is helping these Hondurans and refugees -- were hired by Trump, because it is perfect.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: True.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Again, here is -- just a singular example that underlines the necessity for a plan which is a wall with a door, which is what Trump is talking about. Weaving in a group of illegal immigrants is not a plan. Wall with a door is a plan. So, this, actually, again, validates his concerns over a weak border. Even Mexico knows that this is wrong. They deported tens of thousands of Hondurans. And yet, this is, hey, come on through. So, again, it validates -- and then, back to the point about DACA, who killed DACA. I think the Democrats sacrifice the people they've used as pawns for so long just to score against Donald Trump. This Trump deal would have solve everything.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: . but they didn't want the solution unless it involved a humiliation of Trump, because Trump was giving -- was it 1.6 million?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And it's not the first time that the Democrats did this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean, if you go back to 2007 when that deal was on the table they blocked it then too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. In business, if the deal gives you what you want, it doesn't matter if you don't get along, right? You can get a deal with people you don't like. But in politics, there're no such rules for this. You can kill a deal and get rewarded for it because it rewards your side. There's no political consequences to this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And to your point about the responsibility of both parties scuttling this deal, if you look at the Republicans, a lot of those people in the pocket of big business, they want certain amount of open borders because they want the cheap labor for the companies to come in. And the Democrats, obviously, want open borders because it means more votes and more amnesty. Meanwhile, the middle-class American workers are getting hosed, and the body politic suffers from this. And our national security suffers because you have no idea who's coming in the country. Like Greg said in Honduras, that border with Mexico, they've had a fence on that border too, about 500 miles. And we're spending hundreds of millions of dollars sending it to Honduras and Mexico to make sure they secure that border, and make sure that they root out the corruption and try to help their economy, because right now it's such a disaster, it's spilling over. And no matter what we spend, we're still getting -- I think in 2016, we stopped 200,000 Central American illegal immigrants crossing through Mexico into the United States. That is a lot of people.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: One of the reasons I've look up the Honduras trip that Nikki Haley took, the U.N. ambassador -- there's basically several areas. One was combating drugs and gangs, which is one of the things these people are fleeing from. Economic ties are super important. Valenzuela, again, another huge problem. A lot of people in South America concern about that. But also, remember, it was Honduras and Guatemala, where -- two of the only countries that supported the president on his push to move the embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, I just wanted to jump in and say, Jesse, we have hit a 47- year low in terms of people crossing this border. That you and President Trump want to, I think, create alarmist rhetoric about. Secondly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me finish. Hold on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: . 300,000 people they're catching. How many are they're not catching?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me just say, the numbers, the percentages, the actual count, they don't vary. I mean, that -- this is a 47-year low. They've been using the same count for 47 years.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A lot of that thanks to Trump's rhetoric about building wall.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Because Trump is the wall.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The second thing to say here is these people are coming seeking asylum. In other words, as Dana was just describing the situation in Honduras, this is a humanitarian crisis. And we, as Americans, have created a system that allows people to apply for asylum.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK. You're absolutely right. People should apply. But there's a bit of -- just because they're closer to us isn't fair. There's plenty of people who should be in front of them who happen not to be on our borders. And I could go through them. We know where they are. I just came up with an idea for a CNN town hall.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, no.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Not for Fox News but for CNN. Why, when you talk about all these things that are going on in the world, why is his approval rating still moving up? That's worth discussing. Like, why is it? Is it because of progress on North Korea? Is it because of immigration? Is it because of being tough on China? Is it the second amendment threat? Is it the collusion theory dying?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All of the above.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Is it terror? Is it a Stormy backlash? All of these variables exist. And it kind of makes you think, he might be doing a pretty good job.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yuck.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Do you know why his numbers -- worse of all, the guys is at a record low in terms of approval rating.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I knew your head would explode.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Not only is he on a record low.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wrong.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I think a lot of this, Greg, has to do with people saying, well, he's the president. We're patriots. We're going to support -- you know what.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's a terrible reason.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I agree.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: To support your president because you're patriotic.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No. But all of a sudden that happened. They woke up, they're like patriotism.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The guy numbers still terrible.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's getting better.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The Gallup poll today had him at 39. I want to give Juan a little cover.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. The point I'm trying to make is that every one of these issues that people are throwing out there has a rebound effect and that's what's happening. And Americans are looking at this and they're still looking at the assumptions that Trump makes which is, I'm going to be tough on immigration, law and order. They like that. And all these other things that are going around like collusion, Stormy, they're creating a backlash, he's up at 50 percent.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, please.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: A collusion storm.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Fifty percent in -- that's true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We get there.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Basketball legend Charles Barkley is angry with President Trump and his supporters. You're going to hear why, next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Every now and again, Charles Barkley popped into the new cycle with some kind of tirade against President Trump. The former NBA star now says he's never been more angry and disgusted with the president because of his tweeting and staff changes. And Barkley is unloading on his supporters too.

utterances.speaker: CHARLES BARKLEY, FORMER NBA PLAYER
utterances.utterance: Nobody ever wants to look in the mirror and say it's my fault. I think he reached a demographic that won't look in the mirror and says my life sucks because of me. And he came right after President Obama, and there were some people who are like, wow, we've got a black president. They're not happy with that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wow. All right. Dana, first of all, Charles Barkley is a basketball player.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. He played for the Sixers and the Suns. That's the game where you shoot the ball.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Got it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Got it. All right. So, second of all, one of the biggest mistakes you can make when you're doing, you know, political analysis, and trust me, I know what I'm talking about here. Is that you never go after a candidate's supporters. That, I think, crossing the line.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Did you learn a lot from that, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Thank you, yes. It's very helpful. I'll use it in my future. I do think that life is too short to be mad at people who made a choice based on -- it's not like we didn't litigate the 2016 campaign for two years leading up to it. And people were clear eyed about the decision. And they might have decided, well, I can't vote for her. I'm going to give him a shot. Like, why not? Give it a try. I do try to listen to them, though, because I feel the resentment. I hear it. I don't feel it personally. There is a resentment there that -- as, unfortunately, I think pulling people farther and farther apart. But Hillary Clinton learned that lesson when she said the deplorable.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yep.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . in September of 2016. She was denigrating an entire group of people rather than pulling people together and it's not helpful.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not helpful. So, Greg, Trump flipped 217 counties that went for Obama in 2012.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Does that all of a sudden make people, you know, not racist after four years?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's an irrational comment for him to make, but that isn't news. Guaranteed, if Barkley says something you hate, wait 5 minutes and he'll say something you love. Even in that tirade that he did, he actually said some things that were actually pretty good, about like the Russian thing, the Stormy thing. He is -- he talked about looking in the mirror. He should look in the mirror because he's talking about himself. He is just like Trump. He's an opinionated trash talker. He's run into trouble in his past. He has considered entertaining a career in politics. He would be another Trump. He's upset about Trump tweeting? Charles won't keep his mouth shut if he's president. And I think people -- and Charles is probably in the back of his head thinking, man, I could have done this. I have a pass, but Trump proved that a pass doesn't matter. I could have actually been the governor of a large state or ran for president, which may happen, Charles.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's very authentic and likable guy. And to your point, he did mention something about whether the Russia story was a big issue and we had that. Let's hear it.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: You don't think the Russian thing is an issue?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.utterance: I do not. I think it's probably true that they got -- but I'm pretty sure in area election, state, local, national, somebody can get some dirt on somebody if they wanted to.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: So, you don't think it's a distraction?

utterances.speaker: BARKLEY
utterances.utterance: It's definitely a distraction. We have spent the last year talking about Russia every single day. Now we've got Stormy. Now we've got another girl. And I'm sitting here saying, when are we actually going to help the people?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, Juan, Charles makes a good point there.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I thought that was the best point he make. I mean, to me, the idea that you need to pay attention. I think he mentioned our schools, he mentioned Puerto Rico. You know, the whole idea that even DACA, he mentioned, we should do something to help the dreamers. So, I think on that level, you know, like, let's really help people is what he says is the purpose of government, and he things that we're not doing that job. And I guess that means, by extension, since Trump is president, Trump isn't doing it. But I thought what really struck me was, on some level, you know, we're in the midst of, again, culture wars. And nobody goes to Charles Barkley for political expertise. He was endorsing Doug Jones down in Alabama. As a guy who, at one point, thought about running for governor in Alabama as a Republican. So, I think people say, well, it's Charles Barkley, a celebrity. We like to hear what our celebrities say. But why we take it, like, to heart as, oh, boy, this is big news, I don't know. But he is much more than a basketball player or former basketball player at this point. I think he is, may be, the preeminent basketball analyst in the country. He does not only the NBA, but also the NCAA, and he's very popular. But, I mean, I just think it was interesting, but I don't know that it's any -- of any big consequence.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, people do like listening to Sir Charles, Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's not just a basketball player. He's always said interesting things about politics, pretty in touch with the people.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I think that what we're saying at this table. So, he said a few things in there, it's like Halloween candy. There's some in there I'm like, yeah, I love it. Love it. Candy corn peeps.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're pro-peeps.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes. And then there's like that almond joy, mounds thing, I don't like that at all.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Taste like coconut.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Totally. Only on my skin, you know, like suntan lotion. So, he's like that. He's like a whole bunch of good stuff, and then there's a few things like, man, maybe I'll toss that one out. But I think he's a thoughtful person the way that he comes across. He thinks about things. And I totally agreed with him about the Russia collusion that's just been ridiculous. Like Russia-nitis. And in terms of, you know, what he's saying about those Trump supporters, that I don't like so much.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: . because I think, yeah, a lot of people made choices. And people made choices to go with President Trump with his agenda and reject that of Democratic Party and Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama, which was, sort of, really the establishment that was back in there holding court for a while. So, I mean, I was like listening to what he has to say.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Holding court? Well said, K.G. Ahead, this protest isn't getting much coverage, a student walkout in support of the second amendment, up next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, we saw the March for our Lives a couple of weeks ago. And on Friday, a group of 75 students at a Central Florida high school walked out of class in support of gun rights and the second amendment. Here's one of the students who organized the protest.

utterances.speaker: CHLOE DEATON, ROCKLEDGE HIGH SCHOOL STUDENT
utterances.utterance: It was important to me because the other walkout that happened on March 14 for the Parkland students turned political, and was big support for gun control. And personally, I don't believe that gun-control is the best idea. Everyone has the right to have their own opinion, and I believe that our right should have just been expressed. In the beginning, it was a very big risk to step up and do this. It took a lot of fight with our school to get them to approve it and support us. But in the end, they did support us.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, what's interesting is the media praise for the earlier protest was portrayed as independent of ideology. People that come forth and say, isn't it great that teenagers are going out there and they care about something? That's good. Well, if that's the case, then he should have equal praise for this. If you're independent of ideology, you should say there are kids out there talking about gun control. There kids out there talking about gun rights. Isn't it great that all these kids are out there? But I don't think you're going to see that in the media. On a personal note, I am very, very skeptical of all teenage activism because I was one. I worked on the nuclear freeze. When I was in high school, I did it for extra credit. I got signatures to ban nuclear weapons from being transported in California. I know that I wasn't thinking about it clearly. I know that I was naive and I was doing it for romantic and for extra credit purposes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: For a girl?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That will get the girl. Nuclear freeze.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You have to understand, nuclear freeze and gun-control arguments are the same.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: . in the sense that you're saying, my God, these weapons are for killing. Therefore they are wrong. And that's naive. Because when you grow up, you realize they exist primarily to protect you with the risk factored in.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah. And to prevent war.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And them being used. As a deterrent.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And to protect your house.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: As a deterrent. It's why we also have, like, jails and the justice system. So we say, "Uh-oh, if you mess up, you're going to go there."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: To the big house. OK, Dana, what do you make of this?

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, I love civics education, and studying the Constitution sounds like a really good idea to me. And you can disagree with it. But I loved listening to her, because she's obviously thought it through. And they were able to get their school to agree. You know, they had to persuade them based on some sort of logic to be able to do that. What I would recommend is that the debating association, they choose a new topic every semester for students for the high school debate teams. And I think that gun-control or the Second Amendment should be the one that they do next year. And let these kids argue it. But when you are on the debate team, you don't know if you have to argue pro or con. You have to be well-versed in both, and then you can make a decision at the end of the day. It would be a useful exercise, and I'd love to hear what they have to say.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Perfect. Very good idea. Helpful hints from Dana. Good point journal. OK, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I support both walkouts. One, because if I was in high school, I'd walk out if I didn't have to be in class. And two, you want kids civic-minded. And that's a good thing. Although I think it's --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You want them to buy your future book.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Exactly. In 2030.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And come to your party.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And come to my -- it's so sad. I'll take anybody. But I would say I think it's -- the kids that walked out just recently, I think shows more bravery, because it was very easy to walk out a couple weeks ago. But to walk out on a pro-Second Amendment platform takes a lot more guts. And here's why. Student during the first walkout, some were actually physically assaulted for holding up signs supporting the Second Amendment. One kid was suspended for staying inside the classroom. Other kids were sent home, because they didn't want to participate. With that said, Scott Israel is the real villain here. We really know why -- and that we've been over it 1,000 times. And any day now the Florida Department of Law Enforcement is going to come back with its decision after the investigation into what went wrong, and he may be fired or suspended. And Rick Scott has taken action with the Florida legislature. They've raised the legal limit --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: --- for gun purchases into 21. You have to wait now three days before you purchase a long gun. And they banned sale and possession of bump stocks.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, he's been quite proactive about it and vocal about it right from the beginning. I foresee in our future, a Greg monologue on Sheriff Israel.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, I hope so.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: As it comes down.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Any day.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Wait for it. OK, Juanito.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, everything you just outlined, you know, that Rick Scott did as governor of Florida. Guess what? Your 75 students opposed. So they're opposed to even what a Republican governor in Florida has to do in terms of his response to what's taken place at Parkland. And I think what you're seeing here is really an effort to sort of -- first of all, there were only 75 versus hundreds of thousands that marched around the country.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're in the minority.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: In the polls, polls show overwhelming support for gun control legislation, including universal background checks and the like. This is not, you know, in dispute. But I think what you're seeing here is the right thing. We can produce some students who can march out, because they understand the power of the students who went through the shooting at Parkland. At Parkland, Florida.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Are you are saying this was controlled by the right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, gosh, you know, the sight of so many "Make America Great" hats again might have been a clue.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But that didn't happen in those other protests with other groups?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They supported -- people came into support. But I think what you see here from these students, this 75, is clear support not only for Trump, but they used the kind of language that would make you think, "Gosh. I think these people have -- are being somehow" --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Coached.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- "promoted or coached or something."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But I mean, that was -- that was more transparent in the other protests, because they were so many adults involved and so many celebrities giving money, and so many groups behind them. That was obvious.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And the majority of people that were marching and walking out, being not even teenagers but over that age. And, you know, so it was very well-orchestrated.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And helping them in the green rooms, too.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: But now that it's on the other side, everybody will say, "Oh, no. This is the fake side."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Seventy-five? Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Sometimes doing the right thing is unpopular, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes. Oh, yes. I can see it's very unpopular here.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Always lonely in a crowd.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Isn't it? What does the mainstream media have against fair and balanced news? Greg breaks it down next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If you have a life, then you probably missed this idiotic story making the rounds Sunday on Twitter and CNN -- same thing, really. In a nutshell: Local anchors delivered a message that promised diligence in the fake news era. It's what you'd call a mission statement. But someone compiled the scripted missives, and it was hilarious.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: The sharing of biased --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: -- and false news has become all too common on social media. More alarming, some of the media outlets publishing these same things without checking facts first. Unfortunately, some members of the media are using these platforms to push their own personal bias and agenda.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: This is extremely dangerous to our democracy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: This is extremely dangerous to our democracy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: This is extremely dangerous to our democracy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, my, they were all saying the exact same thing. Who does that remind you of? Hollywood, the mainstream media, the late-night comics? Yet how all these hypocrites whined, the same clacking jaws who get their talking points from Chuck Schumer and Media Matters are mad over this? Shut up. Read the actual script and what do you find? Nothing in there that's pro- or negative Trump, nothing about Democrats or Republicans. Instead, what you'll find is a call for balanced journalism, a concern over unverifiable stories on social media and a criticism of biased broadcasting in general. That sounds pretty healthy to me. Yet our nation's hall monitor clutched his pearls.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: BRIAN STELTER, CNN
utterances.utterance: All these anchors in these markets are required to read this script. It's attacking fake news. But really, what it's doing, it's kind of like the Fox "Fair and Balanced" slogan. It's a way of saying, "We're fair. Everybody else is biased" and it's taking a page out of Trump's playbook.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Come on, Brian. Given CNN's obsession over Stormy, maybe you want to tape this script on the company fridge. And how could it be worse than CNN's mission statement?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED NARRATOR
utterances.utterance: This is an apple. Some people might try to tell you that it's a banana. They might scream, "Banana, banana, banana" over and over and over again. They might put "banana" in all caps. You might even start to believe that this is a banana. But it's not. This is an apple.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Who was high on mushrooms when they wrote that? But Stelter wasn't the only media mouth freaking out. So why was the howling media triggered by this? Well, maybe they feel threatened. People are saying what they're really about, finally. Or maybe, just maybe, this is what angry people do on Easter Sunday and that's even more depressing. So Kimberly, as a mission statement, what exactly was so outrageous about that and the fact that they read it? It was a great audiovisual of putting it together.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right. It was how they packaged it to put it together to make it sound like groupthink.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Like cultish.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Et cetera. Very much like a cult or something like everybody drank the Kool-Aid. The perfect little packet mixture combination of little powder and water for a delightful, delectable thirst-quenching treat. But no, but if you look at it and, like, actually examine the separate and disparate parts, you see it's, in fact, just journalists trying to do their job. But I'm also then reminded in the juxtaposition of how good FOX News is where you look at all the different local clips across. And like, we really do have the best people, I just have to say. Well done.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dana, I think Jimmy Kimmel tweeted that this is a threat to democracy or something like that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I think that also, you have to remember who it's coming from. Right? So this is Sinclair. This is a group that is working on their merger right now. They're super ambitious. They want to be very competitive, including competitive with this network. And what's interesting is I think the way that -- every news organization markets themselves as being the source for truth, the source for the best information --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- the one that you can trust the most. Look across all media. They all are saying that. Some just do it better than others. And I think that there's a lot of consternation about the Sinclair Group, because they're taking over in local media markets that aren't necessarily used to hearing that type of thing, so it does sound weird when it's all in lockstep. Contrast that with the new media campaign that FOX News is doing, which was super sophisticated, very different. And the thing that was really different about it from my perspective is that there was no script. So we went in there not knowing what we were going to be asked or what we were actually going to say. Maybe thought about it a little bit. But all of that is very spontaneous, and authenticity is what I think viewers are looking for. And if you're making fun of that thing, you could probably see that it was not authentic.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: We just showed up with a few different colored outfits.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And then the rest was, like, let it fly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And it's intellectually good. And it's different; it's very modern. And --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. We changed three times.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Nobody was telling us, as every day here, no one tells us what to say --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- what to do, what to think. And that's why it's genuinely authentic, and it shows in the Pew research in the polls. The people trust us.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I still think this is unfair. I think this is a mission statement that they read, and so that's what you do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, they read it, because they can't afford to spend all the money that FOX spends on a really nice promotional campaign. And that's fine. They don't have the budget, so they did what they did. It's the same thing, as you said, as the CNN promo. You hit the nail on the head. CNN is threatened by it, because they know that this Sinclair piece was targeting a place like CNN. You know, this brings me back to the Fake News Awards. Let's remind everybody some of these awards. CNN, Don Jr. and WikiLeaks, false. The Mooch story about Russia, falls. The fake Japanese feeding the fish video, false. Brian Ross, ABC tank market. What do all these things have in common? They're all fake news from the liberal mainstream media, and they were all done in order to hurt President Trump. So when you combine that with the fact that 90 percent of D.C. journalists are Democrats, and 90 percent of the nightly evening news from the networks are against Donald Trump, people understand in this country that the mainstream media is biased, and they calculate that when they watch the news.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Last word, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think it's telling that Donald Trump immediately defended Sinclair. And I think that indicates to me how political this was. So you can say it was a mission statement from a corporate owner, but it's a corporate owner that really controls a lot of local media. And I think the understanding people have when they, you know, if they tune in to us, they say, "Well, that's national media, and I understand the roles that are being played, left, right, all that." But when they turn on their local news to learn about tax assessments in the school board, I think they're surprised that this kind of lockstep, lack of independence would exist. And I think that was the power here. That this is not independent anymore. Your local news is now under control of somebody who is pro-Trump. And Trump is defending them. Because the message, although you see it as not having any bias, it fits the Trump message perfectly, which is you are being assaulted by fake news that's unfriendly to me and not to be believed. And so now coming in your local news, people see this as insidious.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think it actually fits the FOX News message, fair and balanced. That's all they were saying. And No. 2, I would urge people to actually read the actual transcript. Because when you look at the video, all you see in here are the sounds. No one is actually listening. So I think that if you read it, it's not political at all. And it's not Trump. Because remember, Trump came after fair and balanced.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, this is -- this is a context. You have to ask people to read it in the context. They read it without that, they'll say it's no big deal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Read the whole thing. All right. Coming up, Kellyanne Conway responds to allegations she's the No. 1 leaker in the White House.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A new book on the Trump White House making some headlines ahead of its release. This one written by Ron Kessler, who claims he knows where all those leaks are coming from: Kellyanne Conway.

utterances.speaker: RON KESSLER, AUTHOR
utterances.utterance: I know that White House aides have seen texts that she has sent to other journalists dissing her colleagues, leaking material. So if you wonder, you know, why there are so many leaks out of the White House, one reason is Kellyanne is the No. 1 leaker.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: FOX asked Ms. Conway for her response this morning.

utterances.speaker: KELLYANNE CONWAY, COUNSELOR TO DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: He knows, and he has said publicly and privately who the leakers on the liars are and have been. Very happy that there's a lot less leaking in the White House. Leakers get great press. And one day, Abby, I will have my say.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow. So Dana, you're a White House person. What do you think? What's the truth here?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: She's right. Like, the book she writes is the one everyone is going to want to read. Because she'll finally be able to be free and talk about it. I think she is indicating that there was somebody at the White House who is no longer there working at the White House who she thinks was the big leaker. My experience is that people who are the leakers are the one who complain about it first and like saying, like, "Oh, my gosh. Did you see this leak?" And like, oh, yes, you're the leaker. She doesn't seem like the one who does that to me. But I've never been the -- I don't know. I've never been the recipient of any White House leaks, so I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, you would have been the leaker.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No. Let me tell you, communications people don't leak ever.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, is that true?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You have to clean up the mess of everybody else.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's a really good cover.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't think that's -- I don't think that's true, let me just say.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You're telling me White House press secretaries don't leak?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, because you're on the record.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, no, no. They leak. I can personally attest to this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Not me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, not you. I would say not you. Jesse, what's interesting in this is I know Ron Kessler. Terrific reporter but a big Trump supporter, and in fact, someone who's gone down to Mar-a- Lago with Trump, likes Trump a lot. All of a sudden, here he is attacking Kellyanne. What do you make of this?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm confused by it. Kessler is a good author. A lot of the times the books are salacious and gossipy. Although he is a good author, and he does sell a lot of books. I don't know what to think of it. I've always seen Kellyanne as a straight shooter, and she is very supported by the president. One if not the best and most articulate defender of the president of the United States and is one of, if not the best and most articulate defender of the president. So I don't think she's the leaker. I don't know that for a fact, but I do know if Dana was to leak, she would not leak to you, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Is that right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Never. Never.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Excellent.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'd be leaking to Jesse Watters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. That's right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Kellyanne is going to be on "Watters' World"?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It's like --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The truth teller. I call on the truth teller.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, the truth teller. I mean, come on, everybody knows who the leakers are, were, in the White House. Kellyanne not one of them. And so I think when she has her day --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- you know, to be able to tell the truth about what went on there, she's going to have a very revealing and not surprising story to tell in terms of what transpired there. So I've never known her to leak, to do anything like that. And I know other people who have. That's for sure.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So Greg, the one last thing I'd say is that, according to Kessler, Ivanka and Jared are problems. That's what Kessler writes. And he said that they were involved with firing Comey and hiring Scaramucci.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I actually believe Kessler on this, because I don't think that -- what's her name again?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Kellyanne.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Kellyanne, I don't think she's the leaker. I think she's a human being. And this White House is not a perfect White House. It's a human being White House. That means people talk and they complain and they vent. So I don't think anybody is actually leaking. They're just walking around venting, and people hear it. By the way, I have an idea for a sponsored segment on this show. Call it "Leak of the Day." It could be sponsored by Poise. It would be great.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Got to go.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Got to go.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. "One More Thing" -- you want to get out of here. "One More Thing" up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's time now for "One More Thing." Juan hits -- kicks us off. Hits us off?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's April, time for high school college seniors to open those make-or-break college acceptance letters. This year's big winner across the nation is a 17-year-old from Houston, Michael Brown. He got into Stanford, but that's just 1 of 20 schools that accepted the young man. And he got into all of those schools and also got full scholarships to all of them. His mom, who's a drug counselor, says her dreams have come true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's awesome. Good for him. Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, Stanford was my safety school. Nice try.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Nice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The guy in Sarasota, we're going to call him a Florida man, went out to his backyard to go for a swim around midnight, and guess what he found?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, dear.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: An 11-foot alligator swimming in his pool in Florida. He called some people, they said get out of the pool, and he was safe. But I mean, look at that thing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's a big thing.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: My gosh, look at how much fun it was having. It was like how I feel when I'm in the hot tub.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Greg, you're next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. First, if you go to Berkeley, you've got to start making shirts that say "Stanford was My Safety School." You have to do that. All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I want a cut.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I hate these people!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. If you're in a meeting -- let's say it's an H.R. meeting, or its traffic school, or it's records preservation training -- and at the end of the meeting, someone says, "Does anybody have any questions?" Don't ask a question. Nobody likes the person that asked a question, especially when it's nice outside or it's the end of the day. Go -- if you have a question, go on Google.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Find out that question there, answer that question.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's a good answer. Everyone should listen to that. A good point. Everyone should listen to his advice. All right. People who know Jasper know he likes to look for fish. If you follow me on Instagram, he's always every day fishing, everywhere he can. This weekend, not only was it Easter yesterday, but Jasper caught a fish. Check him out. A big one. Check him out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Nice.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The other thing is, it was April Fool's, and I got so many people on that. He didn't catch the fish. Don't forget, "Let Me Tell You About Jasper," it comes out in paperback tomorrow. Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Very, very cute. OK, so a little bit of damp weather was no match for this year's 140th annual White House Easter egg roll. Nearly 30,000 adults and children joined the first lady on the White House lawn. It was packed with fun. Melania Trump, Betsy DeVos and Kellyanne Conway were among those featured as readers this year. And this goes back to 1878.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: A great event. "Special Report" is up next. Hey, Bret.
